Minerva's worship and mythology evolved significantly over time in Rome. 

Minerva was originally a goddess of wisdom, trade, and handicrafts in Etruscan mythology before being adopted into the Roman pantheon. The early Romans saw her as a protector of the city and identified her with their own goddess of wisdom, Athena.

During the Republic era, Minerva became associated with war and was often depicted armed and helmeted. As Rome expanded through military conquests, Minerva became an important symbol of Roman military strength and strategy.

During the Imperial era, Minerva was elevated to the status of a major deity and became associated with the emperor and the empire itself. She was often depicted in imperial art alongside the emperor and was believed to protect the empire and ensure its success.

In Roman mythology, Minerva also became associated with various other aspects of life, including medicine, poetry, and music. She was often depicted as a patron of artists and intellectuals.

Overall, Minerva's worship and mythology in Rome evolved from a local Etruscan goddess of wisdom and trade to a major deity closely associated with Roman military power and imperial glory.
